Award.AwardTitle: Getting to the Root of Flexible Stems: The Primary Cilia as a Proximate Mechanism of Plasticity and Evolution of the Cichlid Jaw
Award.AbstractNarration:
How biodiversity arises and is maintained over time remains an important area of study. Adaptive radiations represent extreme instances of morphological evolution in response to discrete ecological shifts, and are thought to have made significant contributions to biodiversityon this planet. This research seeks to identify and characterize the genetic and cellular mechanisms that promote adaptive radiations, and thus to provide novel insights into the origins of biodiversity. This highly interdisciplinary project provides a rich intellectual landscape to train students in various methods and theories. It also offers an explicit framework to develop pedagogical tools for conveying evolutionary principals to the public. This will be part of on-going efforts to develop a series of animated and interactive evolutionary "origin stories" that detail the genetic mechanisms that underlie the development and evolution of notable traits, including turtle shells, bat wings, and limb loss in whales. Here the team proposes a new chapter-- Making faces: How the fish changes its skull.

A focal point of this project is phenotypic plasticity, which refers to the ability of an organism to change its appearance in response to a change in the environment. The ability of an individual to change its phenotype in different environments may increase its fitness in changing and/or fluctuating environments, which suggests that plasticity may be adaptive and therefore subject to selection itself. It is predicted that species that live in fluctuating environments will maintain a high degree of plasticity. Conversely, species that live in more stable environments are predicted to loose the ability to mount a plastic response, and exhibit fixed phenotypes. Unfortunately, a strict genetic basis for phenotypic plasticity has remained elusive, and thus the evolutionary potential for this trait remains largely unknown. The goal of this research is to characterize the molecular basis for phenotypic plasticity of the teleost jaw. An emphasis on the jaws has direct ecological consequences, as different jaw shapes will determine where a fish lives and what it feeds on. Mutant and transgenic zebrafish will be used to assess the degree to which key molecules involved in bone formation, including those that underlie the primary cilia and Hedgehog signaling, are necessary to promote phenotypic plasticity in the skull and jaws. The molecular mechanisms that underlie plasticity will then be compared to patterns of genetic evolution in a textbook adaptive radiation, East African cichlid fishes, which exhibit extensive diversity in the shape of their jaws. It is predicted that the genes that underlie plasticity of the feeding apparatus, also underlie evolution of the jaws. This is because genetic variation that leads to plasticity is predicted to become "fixed" as populations adapt to new environments over time. In all, research under this award will facilitate a better understand of how the genome and environment interact to promote biodiversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phenotypic plasticity refers to the ability of a single genotype to produce multiple phenotypes under different environmental conditions, and has emerged as an important concept in evolutionary biology. The ability to adapt to environmental change within a single generation may facilitate survival, underscoring the adaptive nature of this trait. Furthermore, plasticity has the potential to bias the direction and/or speed of evolution within a population by changing the phenotypes that are exposed to natural selection. Our understanding of this important phenomenon is incomplete owing to limited knowledge of the molecular underpinnings of plasticity. This open question was the main motivation for undertaking this research, and several important contributions were made to the field through these efforts.

Intellectual Merit - Under this award we characterized the genetic, cellular and developmental mechanisms that regulate phenotypic plasticity of the head skeleton. Contributions include the development of new methodologies, as well as an expanded conceptual understanding of how bone cells sense and response to environmental stimuli, such as mechanical load, to produce more or less bone matrix. In particular, we show that two molecular mechanisms are important in enabling this ability of cells. The first is the primary cilia, which is a complex but common feature of most cells. The primary cilium plays many important roles in the cell including sensing mechanical stimuli. While this organelle is well studied, it is also one of the most complicated features of the eukaryotic cell. Or work focused on a part of the primary cilium for which little is known - the rootlet, which acts to anchor the cilium to the body of the cell, much like the roots of a tree. We show that without this component of the cilium, this structure is lost over time, which in turn leads to degeneration of bone. This insight has important implications of degenerative bone disease in humans. In addition, we find that other cell behaviors are negatively influenced when the cilium is present but not the rootlets, which suggests that rootlets may play roles beyond maintaining the structural integrity of the primary cilium. The second mechanism we identified involves the Hedgehog signaling pathway, which is composed of a well studied group of proteins known to relay chemical signals from outside the cell to inside of the nucleus, leading to changes in gene expression and ultimately cell behavior. This pathway is well studied in development, as well as in human health and disease, but here we show that it is also an important mechanism that sensitizes bone cells to sense and response to mechanical input, revealing an entirely new role for this important signaling mechanism. 

These pathways were already implicated in the evolution of different skeletal shapes in fishes. Here we show that they are also involved in plasticity. These combined insights provide support for a long held evolutionary theory that states that plasticity can bias the direction of evolution if the molecular mechanisms that underlie plasticity and genetically-based adaptation are the same. Thus, our work has made important contributions to our understanding of the origins of biodiversity. 

Broader Impact - This award has helped to support four PhD students, two MS students, one technician, twelve undergraduate credit-based research experiences, six undergraduate honors theses, and six undergraduate summer research experiences. The research skills acquired and honed by students over the course of this award are broad and integrative, and include molecular, statistical and computational methods. In addition, work under this award has contributed to professional development for students in the form of writing and presentation skills (e.g., oral and poster presentations).

Data generated under this award will also form the basis for developing an undergraduate laboratory class as part of my current evo-devo lecture course (to be launched in Fall 2020, servicing 48 students). 

Finally, results have been disseminated through talks given by the lead investigator at universities across the country, as well as by the lead investigator and students at national and international conferences. Three papers are also either in review or in preparation based on data generating under this award.
